It is definitely possible, majority of us might not be able to live in a mansion and enjoy various 'luxurious' experience but making a living with fairly standard level isn't as hard as one might think. First thing you have to do is evaluation. Compared to other occupations, being musician isn't as hard as one would think. Aside from entry or non-skilled job out there, pretty much any profession requires some form of credentials, certificates, and licenses, which mean those people in the fields actually studied, practiced, and acquired both experiences and information whether they like their jobs or not. Having enough musicianship and information is must, this is just to set you on the startline since there's no way of telling who's good or not. If you make mistakes during practice, you will make one at the work. You really have to be very strict on you. Next would be treating your life as a musician more professionally. From social/professional relationship to personal life, you'd have to treat it like anyone out there who's successful in their fields. People used to talk about 10,000-hour rules, but average people with 9–5 jobs usually spend that much, or even more, for their jobs in about 5-year. In a way, musician isn't special, probably closer to average joe or even worse usually. Respect others for who they are, being punctual is given in any industry, not to mention presenting yourself accordingly including appearance and way you speak and behave. Be informed about what's going on around you and the world. Another one that you really need to pay attention is how to handle your music life as a business. Once you decide to pursue a career as a musician, you are becoming a business entity. Practice, recording, and performing or teaching should be the easy and fun part at this point. We are talking about tax, registration, contract, and everything in between. If you are not interested in more business aspect of music and would rather hire someone else means you just need to make way more. Know your right, decline any underpaid offer, negotiate, and make sure to know how to read contact and understand. Also, make sure to do tax. Now to be bit more specific, always try to write and record. Whether it's a demo, EP, or full-length recording, your craft belongs to you and will be a business card to represent you. If you are into teaching, write and prepare your own curriculum. I've been telling this to almost everyone who are trying to attend music school since they will have more resources handy, yet only a few decided to actually do it. Learning and covering other people's music is great but it is part of the 'practice', not career. You really need to have your own thing going on. It is indeed hard to write epic masterpiece from the beginning but that's exactly why we constantly try. Of course, this means you really need to carefully spend limited fund to acquire/update you as a business. Custom/luxury instruments are always tempting but it won't really help in your music life if you don't own any of descent recording equipment. Make some time to meet and engage with people in the industry, but put some distance. Connection is the key in any industry, it informs you even quicker than social media or news, often securing you a job. Remember, there's no ‘indeed’ or so kind of website to publicly post music exclusive work unless you are a teacher or so, many opportunities are still based on word of mouth and you need to let others know that you are available and capable. That being said, don't try to believe everything people say and use your own judgement.just like any other fields, there are always people who'd try to take advantage. Last but not least, make sure to update your repertoire and update yourself frequently. Try not to stuck at old files of music, check new ones out whether they are good or not. Listen to something that you usually don't listen, don't limit yourself by all means and practice/write to acquire something new to learn all the times.
